feature.name: scoped-keyword
feature.para: The keyword means the argument and local variable can only be used inside the method. This means you cannot use this variable and argument outside the scope, such as new RefStructType(scoped_variable), return scoped_variable and field = scoped_variable. Such expressions may store the variables, unsafely expanding the variable's lifecycle.

member.param: The number of elements you want to take.
member.returns:
The subsets of the list. For example, if the input array is [1, 2, 3] and the argument is 2, the result will be

The pattern that reserved characters satisfied. All supported patterns are:

@"\t" To match a tab.

member.remarks: For example, if code is "Hello, world!".Reserve(@"\w"), the return value will only contain the letters, digits or the underscore character '_' (i.e. "Helloworld" as the result of this example).

RegexOptions.Compiled

○ Match a sequence of expressions.
○ Match if at the beginning of the string.
○ Match a whitespace character atomically any number of times.
○ Match a sequence of expressions.
○ Zero-width positive lookbehind.
○ Match the string "\r\n" right-to-left.
○ Match a whitespace character atomically at least once.

summary.para: Interceptors are an experimental compiler feature planned to ship in .NET 8 (with support for C# only). The feature may be subject to breaking changes or removal in a future release.

An interceptor is a method which can declaratively substitute a call to an interceptable method with a call to itself at compile time. This substitution occurs by having the interceptor declare the source locations of the calls that it intercepts. This provides a limited facility to change the semantics of existing code by adding new code to a compilation (e.g. in a source generator).

member.name: P:System.Linq.Providers.ILinqMethod`2.SupportsQuerySyntax
member.summary: Indicates whether the methods defined in type support for query syntax also. By default, the value is .
member.remarks:
All possible query clauses are:
Query syntax Equivalent method
element collection N/A
element1 collection1
element2 collection2
condition
variable = expression
{ variable | expression } [ variable]
{ variable | expression }
{ variable | expression }
{ variable | expression }
{ v1 | e1 }, { v2 | e2 } ...
{ v1 | e1 }, { v2 | e2 } ...
{ v1 | e1 }, { v2 | e2 } ...
variable { variable | expression } [ variable]
expression expression [ variable]
variable collection previousVariable variable
variable2 collection2 variable1 variable2 joinedGroup

member.name: T:System.Linq.TupleEnumerable
member.summary: Provides with LINQ methods for instances.

summary.para: Provides with the type that contains a module initializer method, called automatically by the CLR (Common Language Runtime) to initialize some values.

para.i: The type is called by the compiler and the CLR (Common Language Runtime), which means you cannot use any members in this type manually.

target.name: method
target.summary: Called by the runtime automatically while booting on this solution to initialize the values, data members or any other things that can or should be initialized here.
target.remarks: The concept module is different with assembly. The solution can contain multiple assemblies, while each assembly can contain multiple modules. However, due to the design of Visual Studio project file system, each assembly will only contain one module by default.

member.remarks: Please note, sometimes some extra keywords will be automatically added into signature without manually assigning them to this property. For example, in a non-, due to the implementation not caring about its -ability, a modifier will be implicitly added.

member.name: T:System.SourceGeneration.PrimaryConstructorParameterAttribute
member.summary: Indicates the attribute type that can be marked for a parameter, indicating the parameter is a -like one, telling the source generator that it should generate a property that references this parameter.
member.param: Indicates the member kind to be generated. You can reference the target value via type .

remarks.para: Begin with C# 12, we can define primary constructors for non- types. However, the parameter defined will be expanded as a real parameter in its containing constructor. The compiler won't create a binding field or property. We should define it manually. This attribute will solve this problem.
If you want to learn more information about this attribute type, please visit the metadata of the type.

member.name: M:System.SourceGeneration.PrimaryConstructorParameterAttribute.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Indicates the attribute type that can be marked for a parameter, indicating the parameter is a -like one, telling the source generator that it should generate a property that references this parameter.
member.param: Indicates the member kind to be generated. You can reference the target value via type .

remarks.para: Begin with C# 12, we can define primary constructors for non- types. However, the parameter defined will be expanded as a real parameter in its containing constructor. The compiler won't create a binding field or property. We should define it manually. This attribute will solve this problem.
If you want to learn more information about this attribute type, please visit the metadata of the type.

member.name: P:System.SourceGeneration.PrimaryConstructorParameterAttribute.IsImplicitlyReadOnly
member.summary:
Indicates whether the generated field or property is implicitly read-only. If the property is , the generated data member (auto-impl'ed propertys or fields) will be modified by keyword if all following conditions are true:
The type is a , , (will be included in future C# version) or (will be included in future C# version)
The type is not marked with keyword
However, sometimes we should use non- member as fields or auto-impl'ed properties, but we cannot modify it. By setting the property with value, to avoid the source generator marking the generated member as .
member.remarks: This property is by default.

summary.para: Indicates the extra setter expression. The expression is same declaration as auto-implemented properties.

For example, if the property is declared as public object? Property { get; private set; }, the setter expression will be "private set". By default, this value will be , which means the target property does not contain a setter.

member.name: P:System.SourceGeneration.PrimaryConstructorParameterAttribute.NamingRule
member.summary: Indicates the naming rule of the generated member name.

remarks.para:
The syntax of this property can be described as two parts:
A verbatim symbol @ ("At" symbol, may contain an extra character < or >: <@ or >@)
Characters used in a valid identifier

For example, if you want to set a generated property is named like xxxTargetProperty where the xxx is the name of the generated property, you can set this property as value "@TargetProperty". Then the generated property will be like:
public int ParameterTargetProperty { get; } = parameter;
By default, the naming rule is "_<@" for fields, and ">@" for properties.

member.name: P:System.SourceGeneration.PrimaryConstructorParameterAttribute.MembersNotNull
member.summary: Indicates the member names becoming not when this generated member is or .
member.remarks:
The syntax of this property can be described as two parts:
Boolean value literal
Member or parameter names
The complete expression is "(1): (2)". For example: ": property1, property2". The generated member will be:
[MemberNotNullWhen(false, nameof(Property1), nameof(Property2))] public bool Parameter { get; } = parameter;
where property1 and property2 are supposed to be two parameters marked this attribute.

member.name: P:System.SourceGeneration.PrimaryConstructorParameterAttribute.GeneratedMemberName
member.summary: Indicates the name of the generated member.

member.name: P:System.SourceGeneration.PrimaryConstructorParameterAttribute.Accessibility
member.summary: Indicates the accessibility of the generated member.

remarks.para:
This property controls the case when you want to customize the accessibility of generated member. For example, the value is "private" or "Private", the generated member will automatically insert the accessibility modifier into property declaration:
private int Parameter { get; } = parameter;
By default, the accessibility is for fields and for properties.

member.name: P:System.SourceGeneration.PrimaryConstructorParameterAttribute.RefKind
member.summary: Indicates the kind of the generated member.

remarks.para:
This property controls the case when you want to customize the reference kind of return value of the field or property. For example, the value is "ref readonly", the generated member will automatically insert the modifiers into declaration:
private ref readonly int _parameter = ref parameter;

By default, the kind should be suitable with parameter's declaration. If the parameter is defined without any modifiers:
(Supported in C# 12)
(Supported in C# 12)
(Not supported in C# 12)
(Not supported in C# 12)
(Not supported in C# 12)
the generated member will automatically include a modifier if the modifiers don't include ; otherwise, no modifiers. If you want to set , you should manually set this property with value "ref readonly" value.
